msgSnippet: ... That s not what I was saying.  I am sure your code won t crash if the method is called without these prerequisites, it s just that it won t be doing
messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On

> Not at all. That's what class invariants are for. Each public
> method is atomic. It is invoked when an object is any legal
> state and when the method returns it is always careful to
> leave the object in one of the legal states (barring bad
> synchronization and complicated multithreaded issues).

That's not what I was saying. I am sure your code won't crash if the method
is called without these prerequisites, it's just that it won't be doing
anything useful (no-op or throwing an exception), so testing it in these
conditions will be useless: you need to set up these prerequisites before
you invoke the method.

> However, a situation where public method A must be
> invoked before method B is a code smell.

I see code like this every day, and it's not a code smell to me.

It's just what a program is about: the logical execution of statements in a
certain order. Run them in a different order and the program no longer does
what it's supposed to do.

Seriously, can you take any two method invocations following each other in
your code, swap them, and your code still works?!?
